description: From Urdu شکار‎ / Hindi शिकार (śikār), from Persian شکار‎ (šekâr).

examples: Where other men took ten days to the Hills, Strickland took leave for what he called shikar, put on the disguise that appealed to him at the time, stepped down into the brown crowd, and was swallowed up for a while.

entries.meaning: hunting guide (elsewhere besides India, e.g. Australia)

verbs.description: shikar (third-person singular simple present shikars, present participle shikaring or shikarring, simple past and past participle shikared or shikarred)

entries.meaning: (India, dated, transitive, intransitive) To hunt; to go hunting.
